head.title: AA′-Stacked Trilayer Hexagonal Boron Nitride Membrane for Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells | ACS Nano

meta.content: AA′-Stacked Trilayer Hexagonal Boron Nitride Membrane for Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells

Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and graphene have emerged as promising materials for proton exchange membranes because of their high proton conductivity and chemical stability. However, the defects and grain boundaries generated during the growth and transfer of two-dimensional materials limit their practical applicability. Here, we report the fabrication of membrane electrode assemblies using large-area single-oriented AA′-stacked trilayer h-BN (3L-BN), which exhibits very few defects during the growth and transfer, as a proton exchange membrane for use in fuel cell systems. The fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN showed a H2 permeation current density as low as 2.69 mA cm–2 and an open circuit voltage (OCV) as high as 0.958 V; this performance is much superior to those for cells based on Nafion (3.7 mA cm–2 and 0.942 V, respectively) and single-layer h-BN (10.08 mA cm–2 and 0.894 V, respectively). Furthermore, the fuel cell with the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane almost maintained its original performance (OCV, maximum power density, and H2 permeation current density) even after 100 h of an accelerated stress test at 30% RH and 90 °C, while the fuel cells with the Nafion and single-layer BN membranes exhibited severely deteriorated performances. The stability of the cell based on the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane was better because the membrane prevented gas crossover and suppressed the generation of reactive radicals during cell operation.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and graphene have emerged as promising materials for proton exchange membranes because of their high proton conductivity and chemical stability. However, the defects and grain boundaries generated during the growth and transfer of two-dimensional materials limit their practical applicability. Here, we report the fabrication of membrane electrode assemblies using large-area single-oriented AA′-stacked trilayer h-BN (3L-BN), which exhibits very few defects during the growth and transfer, as a proton exchange membrane for use in fuel cell systems. The fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN showed a H
2
permeation current density as low as 2.69 mA cm
–2
and an open circuit voltage (OCV) as high as 0.958 V; this performance is much superior to those for cells based on Nafion (3.7 mA cm
–2
and 0.942 V, respectively) and single-layer h-BN (10.08 mA cm
–2
and 0.894 V, respectively). Furthermore, the fuel cell with the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane almost maintained its original performance (OCV, maximum power density, and H
2
permeation current density) even after 100 h of an accelerated stress test at 30% RH and 90 °C, while the fuel cells with the Nafion and single-layer BN membranes exhibited severely deteriorated performances. The stability of the cell based on the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane was better because the membrane prevented gas crossover and suppressed the generation of reactive radicals during cell operation.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Atomic-thickness two-dimensional (2D) materials such as graphene and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) are used to form some of the thinnest membranes, owing to their very low transport resistance and very high permeation flux.
(1−6)
In particular, it has been shown both theoretically
(7,8)
and experimentally
(9−12)
that the high proton conductivity of graphene and h-BN makes them highly suitable for proton exchange membranes. Hu
et al
. reported that mechanically exfoliated monolayered h-BN or graphene inserted between two Nafion films shows excellent proton areal conductivity (approximately 0.1 or 0.04 S cm
–2
, respectively, at room temperature and approximately 1.0 or 0.1 S cm
–2
, respectively, at 65 °C).
(9)
These conductivity values are lower than that of Nafion 211 (approximately 24 S cm
–2
at room temperature and approximately 42 S cm
–2
at 65 °C).
(13)
However, the slightly lower proton conductivities of these 2D materials can be compensated for by their atomic-scale thickness. In the case of 2D materials, protons permeate through the pores formed by the electron clouds.
(7−11)
The pores of h-BN are larger than those of graphene because the strong, polarized bonding between the B and N atoms in h-BN causes the valence electrons to accumulate around the N atoms, resulting in uneven electron cloud distributions.
(9)
Thus, the proton areal conductivity of h-BN is higher than that of graphene. Obviously, the inevitable defects present in large-area h-BN or graphene grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) also provide a path for protons and larger species than those, thus enhancing the conductivity but decreasing selectivity.
(1,7,12)

These reports on the high proton conductivity of 2D materials have led to efforts to evaluate the suitability of these materials for use in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs), in which a composite membrane with a sandwich-like structure is formed by inserting a large-area graphene or h-BN monolayer between two commercial Nafion films. The membrane selectivity and DMFC performance are improved because the sandwich-like composite structure prevents methanol crossover.
(14,15)
However, it should be noted that the graphene or h-BN monolayer acts as an additional membrane for proton transport along with the Nafion film which is a primary membrane. Therefore, given their intrinsic defects and grain boundaries, CVD-grown large-area 2D materials cannot be used independently as proton transport membranes in actual fuel cells. As a result, 2D materials currently find limited use in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) even though these materials show high proton conductivity and excellent chemical stability.
(16−20)
To overcome this issue, it is essential to develop methods of fabricating defect-free, large-area, single-crystal h-BN or graphene. Furthermore, multilayers of h-BN or graphene with an AA′ stacking order would be even more desirable, in case unexpected defects are generated in these materials during their production and transfer.

Herein, we report the fabrication of membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) using large-area single-layer graphene (1L-Gr) and h-BN (1L-BN) and trilayer h-BN (single-oriented 3L-BN with AA′ stacking) for use as 2D material-based proton exchange membranes in fuel cell systems. To simplify the handling of the atomic-scale-thickness single-layer and trilayer membranes comprising the MEAs, an interfacial binding layer (IBL) was coated on these membranes. Since 1L-BN and 1L-Gr exhibit intrinsic defects and grain boundaries, the fuel cells with the 1L-BN and 1L-Gr membranes exhibited high H
2
permeation current densities, of 10.08 and 9.1 mA cm
–2
, respectively, at 0.4 V, indicating that gas crossover occurred through the membranes. However, the fuel cell with an AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane exhibited a low H
2
permeation current density at 2.69 mA cm
–2
, which is even lower than that obtained for a fuel cell with a commercial Nafion 211 film (3.7 mA cm
–2
). Furthermore, the results of an accelerated stress test (AST) revealed that the chemical inertness of the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane significantly improved the long-term stability of the corresponding fuel cell. These results indicate that the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane effectively prevented gas crossover which is one of the primary causes of radical formation during fuel cell operation. Also, the AST results exhibit that the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane can be used at low humidity (30% RH) and high temperature (90 °C).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a shows a schematic of the fuel cell with the AA′-stacked 3L-BN membrane. Single-oriented, wrinkle-free AA′-stacked 3L-BN was grown by a previously reported method (see the
Methods
section,
Figures S1 and S2
for growth and characterization details).
(21)
To fabricate a fuel cell with this structure, a modified process based on the use of 2D materials and slightly different from the general process for fabricating PEMFCs was employed (
Figure
1
b). The fabrication process is discussed in the
Methods
section. Step (i) in
Figure
1
b corresponds to the transfer of the IBL/2D material onto the IBL/anode/SiO
2
substrate structure. Spin- or spray-coating the 5 wt % Nafion solution for the IBL was used in the proposed MEA fabrication process in order to form an IBL/2D material/IBL structure, because it is usually extremely difficult to handle 2D materials as they are readily ripped off from the catalyst layer. It should be noted that this IBL layer did not serve as gas diffusion barrier which is an important role in proton exchange membrane (
Figure S3
). The characteristics of the IBL layer are discussed later. A cathode catalyst slurry was then spray-coated on the prepared sample (steps (ii) and (iii) in
Figure
1
b). A hydrogen fluoride (HF) solution was used to separate the prepared MEA from the SiO
2
substrate (step (iv) in
Figure
1
b). The edge of the MEA was then sealed with polyethylene terephthalate (PET) by pressing to allow for easier handling, resulting in an exposed active area with dimensions of 1.5 cm × 1.5 cm (step (v) of
Figure
1
b). The fuel cells were then assembled using the edge-sealed MEA and the gas-diffusion layers (GDLs), bipolar plates, current collectors, and end plates (step (vi) in
Figure
1
b).

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic illustration of fuel cells formed using 2D materials for proton exchange membrane. (a) Schematic illustration of fuel cell formed using AA′-stacked 3L-BN for proton exchange membrane. (b) Schematic illustration of process for fabricating fuel cells using 2D materials. Fabrication process is modified and different from general process for fabricating PEMFCs.

div.div:
Figure
2
compares the performances of the fuel cells formed using Nafion 211 (thickness: 25 μm) and the 1L-BN, AA′-stacked 3L-BN, and trilayered h-BN prepared using a transfer method (3L-BN-transferred, see details in Experimental section) membranes (thickness: 20 μm). For reference, the performance of cell based on 1L-Gr is shown in
Figure S4
. As shown in
Figures
2
,
S4, and S5
and
Table
1
, the cells based on 1L-BN and 1L-Gr showed similar OCV values, current densities, cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves, and H
2
permeation current density values. The OCV values of the fuel cells based on 1L-BN and 1L-Gr were 0.894 and 0.899 V, respectively. Further, the current densities at 0.6 V of these fuel cells were 1.03 and 1.05 A cm
–2
, respectively (
Figures
2
a and
S4a
), while their maximum power densities were 0.68 and 0.67 W cm
–2
, respectively (
Figures
2
b and
S4b
). Finally, the CV curves of the cells based on 1L-BN and 1L-Gr exhibited similar characteristics (
Figures S4 and S5
). To evaluate the permeabilities of the fuel cells based on 1L-BN and 1L-Gr, the H
2
permeation current densities were measured.
Figures
2
c and
S4c
show that the H
2
permeation current densities of the 1L-BN and 1L-Gr cells at 0.4 V were 10.08 and 9.1 mA cm
–2
, respectively. To determine whether 1L-BN and 1L-Gr acted as proton exchange membranes, we prepared an MEA without 1L-BN or 1L-Gr, that is, using the IBL (cathode/IBL/anode) and evaluated its performance (
Figure S3
). The CV results in
Figure S3
(compare to results of Nafion 211 and 2D material-based fuel cell given in
Figure S5
) show that the inclined slope can be attributed to a current flow through the IBL (that is, internal short circuit due to electrical contact between cathode and anode), as the IBL did not actually act as gas diffusion barrier. On the other hand, IBL/2D material/IBL membranes act as proton exchange membranes because 2D materials block electrical contact between the cathode and the anode and gas permeation through the membrane. In addition,
Figure S3b
shows that the H
2
permeation current density at 0.4 V of the fuel cell with only the IBL was 14.5 mA cm
–2
, which is 3.9 times that of the fuel cell with Nafion 211, indicating that a high degree of crossover occurred in the former fuel cell system.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a–c) Comparison of performances for fuel cell using various 2D materials and commercial Nafion 211. (a) Polarization curves, (b) power density curves, and c) H
2
permeation current density results for various 2D materials and Nafion 211. To obtain polarization results, fuel cells are operated at 70 °C and relative humidity 100%. H
2
gas (0.06 L min
–1
) and air (0.246 L min
–1
) were used as fuel and oxidant, respectively. For H
2
permeation current density measurements, H
2
gas was supplied at anode (0.2 L min
–1
), and N
2
gas was supplied at cathode (0.075 L min
–1
). All measurements were performed at atmospheric pressure condition. (d–f) Transport process of protons and hydrogen gases in each membrane. Results in (a–c) are explained by schematic illustrations of proton exchange membranes in (d) 1L-BN, (e) 3L-BN made by transfer repeatedly, and (f) AA′-stacked 3L-BN.

div.div:
Table 1. OCV, Current Density, and H
2
Permeation Current Density Values of Fuel Cells Based on 2D Materials and Nafion 211 Film

The high H
2
permeation current density and low OCV of the cells with 1L-BN and 1L-Gr can be attributed to gas permeation through the defects and grain boundaries generated in these 2D materials during their growth by CVD and subsequent transfer processes. To overcome the limitations of CVD-grown monolayered materials, two types of trilayered h-BN were prepared by transferring and stacking 1L-BN (3L-BN-transferred, which showed turbostratic stacking; see
Figure S6
) and by direct growth (AA′-stacked 3L-BN). To begin with, the H
2
permeation current density of 3L-BN-transferred was lower at 6.32 mA cm
–2
than those of the cells based on 1L-BN and 1L-Gr (
Figure
2
c), and its OCV was higher at 0.919 V (
Figure
2
a). These improvements in the H
2
permeation current density and the OCV can be explained by the structural differences shown in
Figure
2
d,e. As shown in
Figure
2
e, 3L-BN-transferred exhibited turbostratic stacking. Therefore, even if defects and grain boundaries were present in each layer of 3L-BN-transferred, some of them were probably blocked in the stacked 3L-BN-transferred structure, so that crossover through 3L-BN-transferred was reduced. However, the current density of 3L-BN-transferred was slightly lower than that of 1L-BN because 3L-BN-transferred not only exhibited a lower degree of gas crossover but also poorer proton transport owing to the random stacking of the three layers.

On the other hand, the configuration of AA′-stacked 3L-BN ensured proton transport (0.03 S cm
–1
at room temperature, see
Figure S7
for proton conductivity of membranes based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN) and prevented gas crossover (
Figure
2
c). The polarization data, power density, H
2
permeation current density, and CV curves and of the fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN are shown in
Figures
2
a–c and
S5
, while the values are listed in
Table
1
. The OCV and H
2
permeation current density at 0.4 V of this fuel cell were 0.958 V and 2.69 mA cm
–2
, respectively, which are much better than those for the cells based on 1L-BN and 3L-BN-transferred. As shown in
Figure
2
, the current density at 0.6 V of the fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN was 1.0 A cm
–2
, while its power density was 0.66 W cm
–2
; these values are similar to those of the cell based on 1L-BN. It is known that the power density of the fuel cell is affected mainly by the proton conductivity among many factors.
(13)
Thus, it is noted that the difference of proton conductivity of AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN (0.03 and 0.037 S cm
–1
, respectively) is marginal when we consider a voltage loss by proton transport resistance. On the other hand, H
2
permeation current density mainly affects OCV, as shown in
Table
1
.
(22)
The low OCV value due to low H
2
permeation current density means high gas crossover in fuel cells, indicating that reactive radicals are easily formed in the fuel cell. Hence, the H
2
permeation current density is related to the long-term stability of the fuel cell, indicating an advantage of AA′-stacked 3L-BN (see
Figure
4
).

We also confirmed whether AA′-stacked 3L-BN exhibits desirable performance as a proton exchange membrane in DMFCs (
Figure S8
). Based on the power density data given in
Figure S8
, it can be seen that the fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN showed a higher power density (0.134 W cm
–2
) than did the fuel cells based on 3L-BN-transferred (0.100 W cm
–2
) and Nafion (0.110 W cm
–2
) when operated at 70 °C in a 1 M MeOH solution. AA′-stacked 3L-BN reduced the crossover of MeOH without interfering with proton transport, while 3L-BN-transferred, when inserted between two Nafion 212 films in a sandwich-like structure, retarded proton transport because of its turbostratic stacking, resulting in the performance of the corresponding cell being slightly lower than that of the Nafion-based one. These results are consistent with those shown in
Figure
2
.

Chemically inert h-BN is expected to show high stability against the radicals generated during fuel cell operation. To evaluate the stabilities of the various 2D materials, the changes in the OCV values over time of the cells based on 1L-BN, AA′-stacked 3L-BN, and Nafion 211 during the AST were compared, as shown in
Figure
3
. It can be seen that the OCV values of the cells with AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN degraded by 5% at a rate of 0.46 mV h
–1
after 100 h and by 10% at 0.8 mV h
–1
, respectively. On the other hand, the degradation rate of the OCV of the cell with Nafion 211 was 55% at 4.95 mV h
–1
, which is much higher than that of the cells with AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN. Thus, as expected, the OCV degradation rate of the 2D materials was lower than that of Nafion 211 owing to the excellent chemical stability of h-BN.
Figures
4
and
S9
show the polarization curves, power densities, H
2
permeation current densities, and CV curves before and after 100 h of the AST, while the properties before and after the AST are listed in
Table
2
. The changes in the OCV values of the cells based on 1L-BN and AA′-stacked 3L-BN after 100 h of the AST were marginal, while the OCV of the cell based on Nafion 211 changed considerably from 0.942 to 0.6 V. Further, the H
2
permeation current densities of the cells based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN decreased from 2.69 to 2.25 mA cm
–2
and from 10.08 to 9.4 mA cm
–2
, respectively. Thus, the H
2
permeation current densities of the cells based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN were slightly improved. In contrast, the Nafion 211 cell showed sharp changes in its CV curve and H
2
permeation current density, indicating that this cell could not be operated after 100 h of the AST.

div.p:
Figure 3. Evolution of OCV over time of fuel cell using AA′-stacked 3L-BN, 1L-BN, and commercial Nafion 211 during AST. AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN show excellent chemical stability (see red and blue arrows for degradation rate after 100 h AST) compared to Nafion 211 (see green arrow). AST was operated at 90 °C, relative humidity 30%, and atmospheric pressure condition. H
2
gas (0.06 L min
–1
) and air (0.246 L min
–1
) were used as fuel and oxidant, respectively.

Figure 4. (a–c) Comparison of fuel cells using AA′-stacked 3L-BN, 1L-BN, and commercial Nafion 211 before and after AST. (a) Polarization curves, (b) power density, and (c) H
2
permeation current density results for AA′-stacked 3L-BN, 1L-BN, and Nafion 211 before and after AST. In (a) and (b), current density and power density of Nafion 211 dramatically decreased after AST (see green arrow) compared to AA′-stacked 3L-BN and 1L-BN (see red and blue arrows, respectively). From (c), H
2
permeation current density results, degradation of Nafion after AST was confirmed (see change of green graph). The polarization, CV, and H
2
permeation current density results were obtained at same conditions as in
Figure
2
. (d–f) Changes in (d) OCV, (e) maximum power density, and (f) H
2
permeation current density for each fuel cell before and after AST are described.

div.div:
Table 2. OCV, Current Density, Power Density, and H
2
Permeation Current Density of Fuel Cells Using AA′-Stacked 3L-BN, 1L-BN, and Nafion 211 Film: Before and After 100 h of Accelerated Stress Test

Even though the variations in the H
2
permeation current densities of the 1L-BN and AA′-stacked 3L-BN cells before and after the AST were similar, their performances were clearly different in
Figure
4
. The AA′-stacked 3L-BN cell exhibited similar power densities before (0.66 W cm
–2
) and after 100 h (0.63 W cm
–2
) of the AST. In contrast, the power density of the 1L-BN cell decreased from 0.68 to 0.51 W cm
–2
. The 1L-BN cell showed higher permeation current density (high gas crossover) than AA′-stacked 3L-BN cell. Thus, it is expected that reactive radicals are formed easier in the 1L-BN cell than in AA′-stacked 3L-BN cell. This resulted in the degradation of the IBL layers in the 1L-BN cell, indicating the decrease in the power density of the 1L-BN cell after the AST. On the other hand, the power density of the Nafion cell was significantly lower after the AST (it decreased from 0.83 W cm
–2
to 0.45 W cm
–2
, as shown in
Figure
4
b); this result is consistent with the decrease in the OCV and H
2
permeation current density shown in
Figures
3
and
4
. In fact, cross-section SEM images of the Nafion cell showed many cracks and severe degradation in the membrane after the AST, while those of the AA′-stacked 3L-BN cell did not (
Figure S10
). In general, the chemical degradation mechanism of Nafion films involves a two-step process: (i) the formation of reactive radicals by H
2
O
2
, which is mostly generated because the H
2
gas (crossover of hydrogen gas) is changed to reactive 2H and the 2H react with O
2
to form H
2
O
2
(ii) a reaction of highly reactive radicals such as hydrogen, hydroxyl, and hydrogen peroxide radicals with the proton exchange membrane.
(22−24)
These reactive radicals result in the breakage of the carbon–sulfur bonds and sulfonated groups of Nafion to generate OCF
2
and SCF
2
, leading to a decrease in PEMFC performance.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we fabricated MEAs using 2D materials without commercial Nafion films and evaluated the performances of fuel cells based on these MEAs. To improve the OCV values and H
2
permeation current densities of the pristine single-layer 2D materials, AA′-stacked 3L-BN was prepared, and it retarded gas crossover to a significant degree. Moreover, during the AST, the fuel cell based on AA′-stacked 3L-BN exhibited significantly higher chemical stabilities than did the cell based on Nafion, and even after the AST, it was operated without any loss of performance, indicating that it can be operated at low humidity and high temperature. These results highlight the feasibility of monatomic-thick membrane fuel cell using 2D materials as proton exchange membranes, as the fuel cells fabricated using these materials exhibited better thermal and chemical stabilities as compared to those of the cell based on Nafion.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Single-layer graphene was grown on Cu foil (99.8% purity, 0.025 mm thick, Alfa Aeser)
via
low-pressure chemical vapor deposition (LP-CVD) system. Cu foil was placed at the middle of a 2 in. quartz tube CVD system. The furnace was heated to 1000 °C in flow of hydrogen gas (10 sccm). The Cu foil was preannealed at 1000 °C for 30 min. The growth of graphene started by flowing methane gas (10 sccm) for 30 min. After growth time, the furnace was cooled down to room temperature under a low vacuum system.

Single-layer h-BN was grown by a LPCVD method.
(25)
Platinum foil (99.95% purity, 0.125 mm thick, Goodfellow) was placed at the middle of a 2 in. quartz tube CVD system, and ammonia borane (97% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was placed at a subchamber. The furnace was heated to 1100 °C in flow of a hydrogen gas (10 sccm), and the subchamber was heated to 150 °C for the decomposition of ammonia borane. The Pt foil was preannealed at 1100 °C for 30 min under flow of H
2
gas. The growth of h-BN on Pt foil was initiated by opening a valve of the subchamber. After finishing the growth, the furnace was quickly cooled down to room temperature under H
2
gas condition.

Trilayer h-BN with AA′ stacking order was grown by a LPCVD method.
(21)
A sapphire substrate (c-plane) was placed in the middle of a 2-in. alumina tube CVD system, and ammonia borane (97% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was placed in a subchamber. The furnace was heated to 1400 °C under flow of Ar gas (10 sccm) and H
2
gas (10 sccm). The subchamber was heated to 130 °C for the decomposition of ammonia borane. The growth of trilayer h-BN with AA′ stacking order on sapphire substrate was initiated by opening a valve of the subchamber. After opening a valve of the subchamber, the source was supplied for 30 min. After growth completion, the furnace was cooled down to room temperature under Ar and H
2
gas.

div.h3: Characterization of Trilayer h-BN with AA′ Stacking Order
div.div:
The surface morphology of trilayer h-BN with AA′ stacking order was characterized by atomic force microscopy (Dimension Icon, Bruker). Raman spectra were measured by using a micro Raman spectrometer (alpha 300, WITec GmBH) with 532 nm laser. The peak around 1370 cm
–1
corresponds to E
2g
mode. The UV–vis absorption spectrum was measured by using UV–vis-NIR spectrometer (Cary 5000 UV–vis-NIR, Agilent). To obtain low-energy electron diffraction (LEED) (SPECTRALEED, Omicron NanoTechnology GmbH) patterns, trilayer h-BN on Al
2
O
3
sample was loaded in ultrahigh-vacuum system (∼10
–10
Torr). The LEED pattern shows hexagonally arranged spots in
Figure S1e
, rather than a ring-shaped pattern, revealing that the trilayer h-BN is single-oriented over the entire sample.
(21)
For high-resolution imaging and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) of h-BN, low voltage Cs aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy (Titan Cube G2 60-300, FEI) was operated at 80 kV with monochromated electron beam. Since trilayer h-BN was grown with AA′ stacking order, a Moiré pattern was not shown in TEM top-view image in
Figure S1f
, unlike 3L-BN-transferred (
Figure S6
). Also, diffraction pattern of AA′-stacked 3L-BN revealed that h-BN shows AA′-stacking order.

div.h3: Preparation of Trilayer h-BN by Repeated Transfer Method (3L-BN-Transferred)
div.div:
Single-layer h-BN was synthesized on Pt foil substrate by using LP-CVD methods. Poly(methyl methacryltate) (PMMA) was coated on h-BN on Pt foil. By using electrochemical bubbling system,
(25)
PMMA/h-BN was transferred onto SiO
2
substrate. PMMA was removed by immersing prepared PMMA/h-BN into acetone and annealing at 400 °C with Ar atmosphere. Another single-layer h-BN was transferred onto h-BN/SiO
2
sample to prepare PMMA/bilayer h-BN. To remove PMMA, immersion in acetone and annealing process were used. By repeated transfer, trilayer h-BN/SiO
2
sample was prepared.

div.h3: Fabrication Process of Fuel Cells Using 2D Materials
div.div:
We developed a method to fabricate a fuel cell without any damage of 2D materials. The ink of anode and cathode catalysts was prepared by mixing 0.135 g Pt/C (HiSPEC-4000, Johnson-Matthey), 0.932 g of DI water, 0.186 g of isopropyl alcohol, and 0.999 g of 5 wt % Nafion ionomer (1100 EW, DuPont Fuel Cells). All cathodes and anodes had 27 wt % Nafion ionomer. The Pt contents on anode and cathode catalysts were controlled at 0.15 and 0.35 mg cm
–2
, respectively.

The anode catalyst layer, which consisted of the Nafion ionomer and Pt/C, was spray-coated on a SiO
2
substrate (3.0 cm × 3.0 cm). The catalyst-coated SiO
2
substrate was dried completely to remove residual solvent in 80 °C. The Mylar anode sample was hot-pressed to sufficiently flatten the surface of the anode catalyst at 153 kgf cm
–2
and 30 °C for 30 s. In this work, we coated an interfacial binding layer (IBL) using 5 wt % Nafion solution (1100 EW, DuPont Fuel Cells) in the MEA fabrication process to create an IBL/2D material/IBL structure because it is usually difficult to handle 2D materials that can be easily torn on the catalyst layer. Specifically, the structure of IBL/anode catalyst layer was prepared by spin-coating the 5 wt % Nafion solution onto the anode catalyst layer. To form the IBL/2D material/IBL (thickness: 20 μm) structure, a CVD-grown graphene or h-BN sheet (size: 2 cm × 2 cm) was transferred by using the IBL layer instead of PMMA used in a typical transfer process. The IBL/2D material was prepared by spin-coating the 5 wt % Nafion solution onto the 2D material, after which the IBL/2D material was detached from the substrate used to grow the 2D material, and then transferred onto an IBL/anode catalyst layer to complete the IBL/2D material/IBL/anode sample (step (i) in
Figure
1
b). A cathode catalyst layer was then spray-coated on the prepared sample (steps (ii) and (iii) in
Figure
1
b). The cathode catalyst was also dried completely at 80 °C. A hydrofluoride (HF, 10 wt %) solution was used to detach the prepared MEA from the SiO
2
substrate (step (iv) in
Figure
1
b). The edge of the MEA was then sealed with polyethylene terephthalate (PET) by pressing for easier handling MEA, leaving an exposed active area measuring 1.5 cm × 1.5 cm (step (v) of
Figure
1
b).

All single cell experiments were conducted at 70 °C, 100% RH, and atmospheric pressure conditions. The temperature of the gas lines to the anode and the cathode was always set 10 °C above the temperature of the humidifier to avoid condensation of water vapor. H
2
and air gases were used as anode and cathode reactants, respectively. The reactant flow rates for the anode and cathode were 60 and 250 mL min
–1
, respectively. In this work, we conducted a conventional activation by repeating the voltages in a range of potential from 0.8 to 0.3 V until stabilizing the single cell’s performance for 10 h. After confirmation of an open circuit voltage (OCV), the polarization curves were obtained at a scan rate of 10 mV s
–1
from OCV to 0.3 V. The cathode and the anode were purged with N
2
(75 mL min
–1
) and H
2
(200 mL min
–1
), and then cyclic voltammetry (CV) and H
2
permeation current density were measured using an EIS potentiostat. The potential range and the scan rate were 0.04 to 1.2 V (
vs
RHE) and 20 mV s
–1
, respectively. The AST was performed by applying OCV for 100 h under 30% RH, 90 °C, and atmospheric pressure conditions. Three MEAs using each membrane (AA′-stacked 3L-BN, 1L-BN, and Nafion 211, respectively) were fabricated and showed similar performance. Because three MEAs for each membrane showed similar performance at initial measurement, one of the three MEAs was selected for the accelerated stress test (AST).

Selective Gas Transport Through Few-Layered Graphene and Graphene Oxide Membranes
Kim, Hyo Won; Yoon, Hee Wook; Yoon, Seon-Mi; Yoo, Byung Min; Ahn, Byung Kook; Cho, Young Hoon; Shin, Hye Jin; Yang, Hoichang; Paik, Ungyu; Kwon, Soongeun; Choi, Jae-Young; Park, Ho Bum

Graphene is a distinct two-dimensional material that offers a wide range of opportunities for membrane applications because of ultimate thinness, flexibility, chem. stability, and mech. strength. We demonstrate that few- and several-layered graphene and graphene oxide (GO) sheets can be engineered to exhibit the desired gas sepn. characteristics. Selective gas diffusion can be achieved by controlling gas flow channels and pores via different stacking methods. For layered (3- to 10-nm) GO membranes, tunable gas transport behavior was strongly dependent on the degree of interlocking within the GO stacking structure. High carbon dioxide/nitrogen selectivity was achieved by well-interlocked GO membranes in high relative humidity, which is most suitable for post-combustion carbon dioxide capture processes, including a humidified feed stream.

A two-dimensional (2D) porous layer can make an ideal membrane for sepn. of chem. mixts. because its infinitesimal thickness promises ultimate permeation. Graphene-with great mech. strength, chem. stability, and inherent impermeability-offers a unique 2D system with which to realize this membrane and study the mass transport, if perforated precisely. We report highly efficient mass transfer across phys. perforated double-layer graphene, having up to a few million pores with narrowly distributed diams. between less than 10 nm and 1 μm. The measured transport rates are in agreement with predictions of 2D transport theories. Attributed to its at. thicknesses, these porous graphene membranes show permeances of gas, liq., and water vapor far in excess of those shown by finite-thickness membranes, highlighting the ultimate permeation these 2D membranes can provide.

Koenig, Steven P.; Wang, Luda; Pellegrino, John; Bunch, J. Scott

Membranes act as selective barriers and play an important role in processes such as cellular compartmentalization and industrial-scale chem. and gas purifn. The ideal membrane should be as thin as possible to maximize flux, mech. robust to prevent fracture, and have well-defined pore sizes to increase selectivity. Graphene is an excellent starting point for developing size-selective membranes because of its at. thickness, high mech. strength, relative inertness and impermeability to all std. gases. However, pores that can exclude larger mols. but allow smaller mols. to pass through would have to be introduced into the material. Here, we show that UV-induced oxidative etching can create pores in micrometer-sized graphene membranes, and the resulting membranes can be used as mol. sieves. A pressurized blister test and mech. resonance are used to measure the transport of a range of gases (H2, CO2, Ar, N2, CH4 and SF6) through the pores. The exptl. measured leak rate, sepn. factors and Raman spectrum agree well with models based on effusion through a small no. of angstrom-sized pores.

Extensive environmental pollution caused by worldwide industrialization and population growth has led to a water shortage. This problem lowers the quality of human life and wastes a large amt. of money worldwide each year due to the related consequences. One main soln. for this challenge is water purifn. State-of-the-art water purifn. necessitates the implementation of novel materials and technologies that are cost and energy efficient. In this regard, graphene nanomaterials, with their unique physicochem. properties, are an optimum choice. These materials offer extraordinarily high surface area, mech. durability, at. thickness, nanosized pores and reactivity toward polar and non-polar water pollutants. These characteristics impart high selectivity and water permeability, and thus provide excellent water purifn. efficiency. This review introduces the potential of graphene membranes for water desalination. Although literature reviews have mostly concerned graphene's capability for the adsorption and photocatalysis of water pollutants, updated knowledge related to its sieving properties is quite limited.

Two-dimensional (2D) materials of at. thickness have emerged as nano-building blocks to develop high-performance sepn. membranes that feature unique nanopores and/or nanochannels. These 2D-material membranes exhibit extraordinary permeation properties, opening a new avenue to ultra-fast and highly selective membranes for water and gas sepn. Summarized in this Minireview are the latest ground-breaking studies in 2D-material membranes as nanosheet and laminar membranes, with a focus on starting materials, nanostructures, and transport properties. Challenges and future directions of 2D-material membranes for wide implementation are discussed briefly.

Proton and hydrogen transport through two-dimensional monolayers
Seel, Max; Pandey, Ravindra
2D Materials

Diffusion of protons and hydrogen atoms in two-dimensional materials is investigated. Specifically, d. functional calcns. were performed on graphene, hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), phosphorene, silicene, and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) monolayers to study the surface interaction and penetration barriers for protons and hydrogen atoms employing finite cluster models. The calcd. barrier heights correlate approx. with the size of the opening formed by the three-fold open sites in the monolayers considered. They range from 1.56 eV (proton) and 4.61 eV (H) for graphene to 0.12 eV (proton) and 0.20 eV (H) for silicene. The results indicate that only graphene and h-BN monolayers have the potential for membranes with high selective permeability. The MoS2 monolayer behaves differently: protons and H atoms become trapped between the outer S layers in the Mo plane in a well with a depth of 1.56 eV (proton) and 1.5 eV (H atom), possibly explaining why no proton transport was detected, suggesting MoS2 as a hydrogen storage material instead. For graphene and h-BN, off-center proton penetration reduces the barrier to 1.38 eV for graphene and 0.11 eV for h-BN. In defective graphene, the smallest barrier for proton diffusion (1.05 eV) is found for an oxygen terminated defect. Therefore, it seems more likely that thermal protons can penetrate a monolayer of h-BN but not graphene and defects are necessary to facilitate the proton transport in graphene.

Theoretical understanding of mechanisms of proton exchange membranes made of 2D crystals with ultrahigh selectivity
Shi, Le; Xu, Ao; Chen, Guanhua; Zhao, Tianshou
Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters

Recent reports on proton conduction across pristine graphene and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) provide a new avenue for the design of proton exchange membranes. The uniform pores formed by the electron clouds of two-dimensional (2D) crystals can effectively block the undesired transportation of other species thus ultrahigh selectivity can be achieved. With the aid of first-principles calcns., we investigate the proton conduction process across six kinds of intact 2D crystals, namely graphene, h-BN, β12 boron sheet, χ3 boron sheet, phosphorene, and silicene. To clarify the proton conduction mechanism, three proton penetration modes are proposed: dissocn.-penetration, adsorption-penetration, and direct penetration. Based on our calcn. results, for graphene and h-BN without at. defects, they are unlikely to provide sufficient proton cond. at room temp. when no bias potential is applied. By contrast, the β12 boron sheet, χ3 boron sheets, and silicene exhibit relatively lower proton penetration energy barriers, making them prospective candidates for future proton exchange membrane applications.

Proton transport through one-atom-thick crystals
Hu, S.; Lozada-Hidalgo, M.; Wang, F. C.; Mishchenko, A.; Schedin, F.; Nair, R. R.; Hill, E. W.; Boukhvalov, D. W.; Katsnelson, M. I.; Dryfe, R. A. W.; Grigorieva, I. V.; Wu, H. A.; Geim, A. K.

(

.

Nature Publishing Group
)
Graphene is increasingly explored as a possible platform for developing novel sepn. technologies. This interest has arisen because it is a maximally thin membrane that, once perforated with at. accuracy, may allow ultrafast and highly selective sieving of gases, liqs., dissolved ions and other species of interest. However, a perfect graphene monolayer is impermeable to all atoms and mols. under ambient conditions: even hydrogen, the smallest of atoms, is expected to take billions of years to penetrate graphene's dense electronic cloud. Only accelerated atoms possess the kinetic energy required to do this. The same behavior might reasonably be expected in the case of other atomically thin crystals. Here the authors report transport and mass spectroscopy measurements which establish that monolayers of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) are highly permeable to thermal protons under ambient conditions, whereas no proton transport is detected for thicker crystals such as monolayer molybdenum disulfide, bilayer graphene or multilayer hBN. Protons present an intermediate case between electrons (which can tunnel easily through atomically thin barriers) and atoms, yet the authors' measured transport rates are unexpectedly high and raise fundamental questions about the details of the transport process. The authors see the highest room-temp. proton cond. with monolayer hBN, for which the authors measure a resistivity to proton flow of ∼10 Ω cm2 and a low activation energy of ∼0.3 electronvolts. At higher temps., hBN is outperformed by graphene, the resistivity of which is estd. to fall <10-3 Ω cm2 >250°. Proton transport can be further enhanced by decorating the graphene and hBN membranes with catalytic metal nanoparticles. The high, selective proton cond. and stability make 1-atom-thick crystals promising candidates for use in many hydrogen-based technologies.

One-atom-thick crystals are impermeable to atoms and mols., but hydrogen ions (thermal protons) penetrate through them. Monolayers of graphene and boron nitride can be used to sep. hydrogen ion isotopes. Using elec. measurements and mass spectrometry, deuterons permeate through these crystals much slower than protons, resulting in a sepn. factor of ≈10 at room temp. The isotope effect is attributed to a difference of ≈60 milli-eV between zero-point energies of incident protons and deuterons, which translates into the equiv. difference in the activation barriers posed by two-dimensional crystals. In addn. to providing insight into the proton transport mechanism, the demonstrated approach offers a competitive and scalable way for hydrogen isotope enrichment.

Thousands of tons of isotopic mixts. are processed annually for heavy-water prodn. and tritium decontamination. The existing technologies remain extremely energy intensive and require large capital investments. New approaches are needed to reduce the industry's footprint. Recently, micrometre-size crystals of graphene are shown to act as efficient sieves for hydrogen isotopes pumped through graphene electrochem. Here we report a fully-scalable approach, using graphene obtained by chem. vapor deposition, which allows a proton-deuteron sepn. factor of around 8, despite cracks and imperfections. The energy consumption is projected to be orders of magnitude smaller with respect to existing technologies. A membrane based on 30 m2 of graphene, a readily accessible amt., could provide a heavy-water output comparable to that of modern plants. Even higher efficiency is expected for tritium sepn. With no fundamental obstacles for scaling up, the technol.'s simplicity, efficiency and green credentials call for consideration by the nuclear and related industries.

Proton transfer across single-layer graphene proceeds with large computed energy barriers and is therefore thought to be unfavorable at room temp. unless nanoscale holes or dopants are introduced, or a potential bias is applied. Here we subject single-layer graphene supported on fused silica to cycles of high and low pH, and show that protons transfer reversibly from the aq. phase through the graphene to the other side where they undergo acid-base chem. with the silica hydroxyl groups. After ruling out diffusion through macroscopic pinholes, the protons are found to transfer through rare, naturally occurring at. defects. Computer simulations reveal low energy barriers of 0.61-0.75 eV for aq. proton transfer across hydroxyl-terminated at. defects that participate in a Grotthuss-type relay, while pyrylium-like ether terminations shut down proton exchange. Unfavorable energy barriers to helium and hydrogen transfer indicate the process is selective for aq. protons.

Nafion 211 is the membrane of ref. for many fuel cell users, but the literature on its properties is sparse. Unlike previous embodiments of Nafion membranes, which are obtained by melt extrusion, Nafion 211 is prepd. by dispersion casting. This paper reports a range of properties obtained by ex situ and in situ characterization methods. Water uptake and proton cond. are studied as a function of temp. and relative humidity. The extent of dimensional changes of as-received membranes upon hydration is found to be independent of thermal treatment. At 25 °C and 97% RH the max. hydration no. is ∼12. Absorption from liq. water and vapor are obsd. to be similar. Proton cond. for Nafion 211 is reported up 80 °C and as a function of relative humidity. At 80 °C, the cond. increases from 0.0012 to 0.13 S/cm as RH is increased from 10 to 95%. The hydraulic permeability of Nafion 211 is 2.4 × 10-16 m2 Pa-1 s-1 at 70 °C and the permeance is 8.8 × 10-12 m Pa-1 s-1. Oxygen soly. and the diffusion coeff., studied using a solid state electrochem. cell, are 1.6 × 10-5 mol cm-3 and 1.04 × 10-6 cm2 s-1 at 30 °C, 100% RH, and 30 psi oxygen. Oxygen permeability is 1.71 × 10-11 mol cm-1 s-1 under similar conditions. In situ measurement of hydrogen crossover current is 1.2 mA/cm2 at 80 °C and 100% RH.

Methanol crossover due to the low selectivity of proton exchange membranes is a long-standing issue in direct methanol fuel cell technol. Here this issue is addressed by designing a composite membrane fabricated by sandwiching a monolayer graphene between two thin Nafion membranes to take advantage of monolayer graphene's selective permeability to only protons. The methanol permeability of the present membrane is demonstrated to have a 68.6% decrease in comparison to that of the pristine Nafion membrane. The test in a passive direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) shows that the designed membrane retains high proton cond. while substantially suppressing methanol crossover. As a result, the present membrane enables the passive DMFC to exhibit a decent performance even at a methanol concn. as high as 10.0 M.

The authors report the use of atomically thin layers of graphene as a protective coating that inhibits corrosion of underlying metals. Here, the authors employ electrochem. methods to study the corrosion inhibition of Cu and Ni by either growing graphene on these metals, or by mech. transferring multilayer graphene onto them. Cyclic voltammetry measurements reveal that the graphene coating effectively suppresses metal oxidn. and O redn. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy measurements suggest that while graphene itself is not damaged, the metal under it is corroded at cracks in the graphene film. Finally, the authors use Tafel anal. to quantify the corrosion rates of samples with and without graphene coatings. Cu films coated with graphene grown via CVD are corroded 7 times slower in an aerated Na2SO4 soln. as compared to the corrosion rate of bare Cu. Tafel anal. reveals that Ni with a multilayer graphene film grown on it corrodes 20 times slower while Ni surfaces coated with four layers of mech. transferred graphene corrode 4 times slower than bare Ni. These findings establish graphene as the thinnest known corrosion-protecting coating.

Corrosion-protective coatings for silicate glass based on the transfer of one or two layers of graphene grown on copper by chem. vapor deposition have been demonstrated. The effectiveness of graphene to act as a glass corrosion inhibitor was evaluated by water immersion testing. After 120 days of immersion in water, bare glass samples had a significant increase in surface roughness and defects, which resulted in a marked redn. in fracture strength. In contrast, the single- and double-layer graphene-coated glasses experienced negligible changes in both fracture strength and surface roughness. The anticorrosion mechanism was also studied.

Recent dramatic progress in studying various 2-dimensional at. crystals and their heterostructures calls for better and more detailed understanding of their crystallog., reconstruction, stacking order, etc. For this, direct imaging and identification of each and every atom is essential. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) are ideal and perhaps the only tools for such studies. However, the electron beam can in some cases induce dramatic structure changes, and radiation damage becomes an obstacle in obtaining the desired information in imaging and chem. anal. in the (S)TEM. This is the case of 2-dimensional materials such as molybdenum disulfide MoS2, but also of many biol. specimens, mols., and proteins. Thus, minimizing damage to the specimen is essential for optimum microscopic anal. Here, the authors demonstrate, on the example of MoS2, that encapsulation of such crystals between two layers of graphene allows for a dramatic improvement in stability of the studied 2-dimensional crystal and permits careful control over the defect nature and formation in it. They present STEM data collected from single-layer MoS2 samples prepd. for observation in the microscope through three distinct procedures. The fabricated single-layer MoS2 samples were either left bare (pristine), placed atop a single-layer of graphene, or finally encapsulated between single graphene layers. Their behavior under the electron beam is carefully compared, and the authors show that the MoS2 sample sandwiched between the graphene layers has the highest durability and lowest defect formation rate compared to the other two samples, for very similar exptl. conditions.

An insulating 2-dimensional material, hexagonal BN (h-BN), is reported, which can be used as an effective wrapping layer for SERS substrates. This material exhibits outstanding characteristics such as its crystallinity, impermeability, and thermal conductance. Improved SERS sensitivity is confirmed for Au substrates wrapped with h-BN, the mechanism of which is studied via h-BN thickness-dependent expts. combined with theor. simulations. The studies reveal that a stronger electromagnetic field can be generated at the narrowed gap of the h-BN surface, which results in higher Raman sensitivity. The h-BN-wrapped Au substrate shows extraordinary stability against photothermal and oxidative damages. Its capability to detect specific chems. that are difficult to analyze using conventional SERS substrates is described. Probably this concept of using an h-BN insulating layer to protect metallic or plasmonic materials will be widely used not only in the field of SERS but also in the broader study of plasmonic and optoelectronic devices.

Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have recently received increasing attention because of their potential applications in semiconducting and optoelectronic devices exhibiting large optical absorptions in the visible range. However, some studies have reported that the grain boundaries of TMDs can be easily degraded by the presence of oxygen in water and by UV irradn., ozone, and heating under ambient conditions. We herein demonstrate the photodegrdn. of WSe2 and MoSe2 by laser exposure (532 nm) and the subsequent prevention of this photodegrdn. by encapsulation with hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) layers. The photodegrdn. was monitored by variation in peak intensities in the Raman and photoluminescence spectra. The rapid photodegrdn. of WSe2 under air occurred at a laser power of ≥0.5 mW and was not obsd. to any extent at ≤0.1 mW. However, in the presence of a water droplet, the photodegrdn. of WSe2 was accelerated and took place even at 0.1 mW. We examd. the encapsulation of WSe2 with h-BN and found that this prevented photodegrdn. However, a single layer of h-BN was not sufficient to fully prevent this photodegrdn., and so a triple layer of h-BN was employed. We also demonstrated that the photodegrdn. of MoSe2 was prevented by encapsulation with h-BN layers. On the basis of XPS and scanning photoemission microscopy data, we detd. that this degrdn. was caused by the photoinduced oxidn. of TMDs. These results can be used to develop a general strategy for improving the stability of 2D materials in practical applications.

Large-scale growth of high-quality hexagonal boron nitride has been a challenge in two-dimensional-material-based electronics. Herein, we present wafer-scale and wrinkle-free epitaxial growth of multilayer hexagonal boron nitride on a sapphire substrate by using high-temp. and low-pressure chem. vapor deposition. Microscopic and spectroscopic investigations and theor. calcns. reveal that synthesized hexagonal boron nitride has a single rotational orientation with AA' stacking order. A facile method for transferring hexagonal boron nitride onto other target substrates was developed, which provides the opportunity for using hexagonal boron nitride as a substrate in practical electronic circuits. A graphene field effect transistor fabricated on our hexagonal boron nitride sheets shows clear quantum oscillation and highly improved carrier mobility because the ultraflatness of the hexagonal boron nitride surface can reduce the substrate-induced degrdn. of the carrier mobility of two-dimensional materials.

A review. Besides cost redn., durability is the most important issue to be solved before commercialization of PEM Fuel Cells can be successful. For a fuel cell operating under const. load conditions, at a relative humidity close to 100% and at a temp. of max. 75 °C, using optimal stack and flow design, the voltage degrdn. can be as low as 1-2 μV·h. However, the degrdn. rates can increase by orders of magnitude when conditions include some of the following, i.e. load cycling, start-stop cycles, low humidification or humidification cycling, temps. of 90 °C or higher and fuel starvation. This review paper aims at assessing the degrdn. mechanisms of membranes, electrodes, bipolar plates and seals. By collecting long-term expts. as well, the relative importance of these degrdn. mechanisms and the operating conditions become apparent.

Results are reported of quantum mechanics (QM) mechanistic studies of Nafion membrane degrdn. in a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell. Expts. suggest that Nafion degrdn. is caused by generation of trace radical species (such as OH·, H·) only when in the presence of H2, O2, and Pt. DFT is used to construct the potential energy surfaces for various plausible reactions involving intermediates that might be formed when Nafion is exposed to H2 (or H+) and O2 in the presence of the Pt catalyst. A barrier of 0.53 eV was found for OH radical formation from HOOH chemisorbed on Pt(111) and of 0.76 eV from chemisorbed OOHad, suggesting that OH might be present during the oxygen redn. reaction, particularly when the fuel cell is turned on and off. Based on the QM, 2 chem. mechanisms for OH radical attack on the Nafion polymer are proposed: (1) OH attack on the S-C bond to form H2SO4 plus a carbon radical (barrier: 0.96 eV) followed by decompn. of the carbon radical to form an epoxide (barrier: 1.40 eV). (2) OH attack on H2 crossover gas to form hydrogen radical (barrier: 0.04 eV), which subsequently attacks a C-F bond to form HF plus carbon radicals (barrier as low as 1.00 eV). This carbon radical can then decomp. to form a ketone plus a carbon radical with a barrier of 0.86 eV. The products (HF, OCF2, SCF2) of these proposed mechanisms have all been obsd. by F NMR in the fuel cell exit gases along with the decrease in pH expected from proposed mechanism.

Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) is gaining significant attention as a two-dimensional dielec. material, along with graphene and other such materials. Herein, we demonstrate the growth of highly cryst., single-layer h-BN on Pt foil through a low-pressure chem. vapor deposition method that allowed h-BN to be grown over a wide area (8 × 25 mm2). An electrochem. bubbling-based method was used to transfer the grown h-BN layer from the Pt foil onto an arbitrary substrate. This allowed the Pt foil, which was not consumed during the process, to be recycled repeatedly. The UV-visible absorption spectrum of the single-layer h-BN suggested an optical band gap of 6.06 eV, while a high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy image of the same showed the presence of distinct hexagonal arrays of B and N atoms, which were indicative of the highly cryst. nature and single-atom thickness of the h-BN layer. This method of growing single-layer h-BN over large areas was also compatible with use of a sapphire substrate.

Kim, Hyo Won; Yoon, Hee Wook; Yoon, Seon-Mi; Yoo, Byung Min; Ahn, Byung Kook; Cho, Young Hoon; Shin, Hye Jin; Yang, Hoichang; Paik, Ungyu; Kwon, Soongeun; Choi, Jae-Young; Park, Ho Bum

Graphene is a distinct two-dimensional material that offers a wide range of opportunities for membrane applications because of ultimate thinness, flexibility, chem. stability, and mech. strength. We demonstrate that few- and several-layered graphene and graphene oxide (GO) sheets can be engineered to exhibit the desired gas sepn. characteristics. Selective gas diffusion can be achieved by controlling gas flow channels and pores via different stacking methods. For layered (3- to 10-nm) GO membranes, tunable gas transport behavior was strongly dependent on the degree of interlocking within the GO stacking structure. High carbon dioxide/nitrogen selectivity was achieved by well-interlocked GO membranes in high relative humidity, which is most suitable for post-combustion carbon dioxide capture processes, including a humidified feed stream.

A two-dimensional (2D) porous layer can make an ideal membrane for sepn. of chem. mixts. because its infinitesimal thickness promises ultimate permeation. Graphene-with great mech. strength, chem. stability, and inherent impermeability-offers a unique 2D system with which to realize this membrane and study the mass transport, if perforated precisely. We report highly efficient mass transfer across phys. perforated double-layer graphene, having up to a few million pores with narrowly distributed diams. between less than 10 nm and 1 μm. The measured transport rates are in agreement with predictions of 2D transport theories. Attributed to its at. thicknesses, these porous graphene membranes show permeances of gas, liq., and water vapor far in excess of those shown by finite-thickness membranes, highlighting the ultimate permeation these 2D membranes can provide.

Selective molecular sieving through porous graphene
Koenig, Steven P.; Wang, Luda; Pellegrino, John; Bunch, J. Scott

Membranes act as selective barriers and play an important role in processes such as cellular compartmentalization and industrial-scale chem. and gas purifn. The ideal membrane should be as thin as possible to maximize flux, mech. robust to prevent fracture, and have well-defined pore sizes to increase selectivity. Graphene is an excellent starting point for developing size-selective membranes because of its at. thickness, high mech. strength, relative inertness and impermeability to all std. gases. However, pores that can exclude larger mols. but allow smaller mols. to pass through would have to be introduced into the material. Here, we show that UV-induced oxidative etching can create pores in micrometer-sized graphene membranes, and the resulting membranes can be used as mol. sieves. A pressurized blister test and mech. resonance are used to measure the transport of a range of gases (H2, CO2, Ar, N2, CH4 and SF6) through the pores. The exptl. measured leak rate, sepn. factors and Raman spectrum agree well with models based on effusion through a small no. of angstrom-sized pores.

Extensive environmental pollution caused by worldwide industrialization and population growth has led to a water shortage. This problem lowers the quality of human life and wastes a large amt. of money worldwide each year due to the related consequences. One main soln. for this challenge is water purifn. State-of-the-art water purifn. necessitates the implementation of novel materials and technologies that are cost and energy efficient. In this regard, graphene nanomaterials, with their unique physicochem. properties, are an optimum choice. These materials offer extraordinarily high surface area, mech. durability, at. thickness, nanosized pores and reactivity toward polar and non-polar water pollutants. These characteristics impart high selectivity and water permeability, and thus provide excellent water purifn. efficiency. This review introduces the potential of graphene membranes for water desalination. Although literature reviews have mostly concerned graphene's capability for the adsorption and photocatalysis of water pollutants, updated knowledge related to its sieving properties is quite limited.

Two-dimensional (2D) materials of at. thickness have emerged as nano-building blocks to develop high-performance sepn. membranes that feature unique nanopores and/or nanochannels. These 2D-material membranes exhibit extraordinary permeation properties, opening a new avenue to ultra-fast and highly selective membranes for water and gas sepn. Summarized in this Minireview are the latest ground-breaking studies in 2D-material membranes as nanosheet and laminar membranes, with a focus on starting materials, nanostructures, and transport properties. Challenges and future directions of 2D-material membranes for wide implementation are discussed briefly.

Proton and hydrogen transport through two-dimensional monolayers
Seel, Max; Pandey, Ravindra
2D Materials
(
2016
),

Diffusion of protons and hydrogen atoms in two-dimensional materials is investigated. Specifically, d. functional calcns. were performed on graphene, hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), phosphorene, silicene, and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) monolayers to study the surface interaction and penetration barriers for protons and hydrogen atoms employing finite cluster models. The calcd. barrier heights correlate approx. with the size of the opening formed by the three-fold open sites in the monolayers considered. They range from 1.56 eV (proton) and 4.61 eV (H) for graphene to 0.12 eV (proton) and 0.20 eV (H) for silicene. The results indicate that only graphene and h-BN monolayers have the potential for membranes with high selective permeability. The MoS2 monolayer behaves differently: protons and H atoms become trapped between the outer S layers in the Mo plane in a well with a depth of 1.56 eV (proton) and 1.5 eV (H atom), possibly explaining why no proton transport was detected, suggesting MoS2 as a hydrogen storage material instead. For graphene and h-BN, off-center proton penetration reduces the barrier to 1.38 eV for graphene and 0.11 eV for h-BN. In defective graphene, the smallest barrier for proton diffusion (1.05 eV) is found for an oxygen terminated defect. Therefore, it seems more likely that thermal protons can penetrate a monolayer of h-BN but not graphene and defects are necessary to facilitate the proton transport in graphene.

Shi, Le; Xu, Ao; Chen, Guanhua; Zhao, Tianshou

Recent reports on proton conduction across pristine graphene and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) provide a new avenue for the design of proton exchange membranes. The uniform pores formed by the electron clouds of two-dimensional (2D) crystals can effectively block the undesired transportation of other species thus ultrahigh selectivity can be achieved. With the aid of first-principles calcns., we investigate the proton conduction process across six kinds of intact 2D crystals, namely graphene, h-BN, β12 boron sheet, χ3 boron sheet, phosphorene, and silicene. To clarify the proton conduction mechanism, three proton penetration modes are proposed: dissocn.-penetration, adsorption-penetration, and direct penetration. Based on our calcn. results, for graphene and h-BN without at. defects, they are unlikely to provide sufficient proton cond. at room temp. when no bias potential is applied. By contrast, the β12 boron sheet, χ3 boron sheets, and silicene exhibit relatively lower proton penetration energy barriers, making them prospective candidates for future proton exchange membrane applications.

Graphene is increasingly explored as a possible platform for developing novel sepn. technologies. This interest has arisen because it is a maximally thin membrane that, once perforated with at. accuracy, may allow ultrafast and highly selective sieving of gases, liqs., dissolved ions and other species of interest. However, a perfect graphene monolayer is impermeable to all atoms and mols. under ambient conditions: even hydrogen, the smallest of atoms, is expected to take billions of years to penetrate graphene's dense electronic cloud. Only accelerated atoms possess the kinetic energy required to do this. The same behavior might reasonably be expected in the case of other atomically thin crystals. Here the authors report transport and mass spectroscopy measurements which establish that monolayers of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) are highly permeable to thermal protons under ambient conditions, whereas no proton transport is detected for thicker crystals such as monolayer molybdenum disulfide, bilayer graphene or multilayer hBN. Protons present an intermediate case between electrons (which can tunnel easily through atomically thin barriers) and atoms, yet the authors' measured transport rates are unexpectedly high and raise fundamental questions about the details of the transport process. The authors see the highest room-temp. proton cond. with monolayer hBN, for which the authors measure a resistivity to proton flow of ∼10 Ω cm2 and a low activation energy of ∼0.3 electronvolts. At higher temps., hBN is outperformed by graphene, the resistivity of which is estd. to fall <10-3 Ω cm2 >250°. Proton transport can be further enhanced by decorating the graphene and hBN membranes with catalytic metal nanoparticles. The high, selective proton cond. and stability make 1-atom-thick crystals promising candidates for use in many hydrogen-based technologies.

One-atom-thick crystals are impermeable to atoms and mols., but hydrogen ions (thermal protons) penetrate through them. Monolayers of graphene and boron nitride can be used to sep. hydrogen ion isotopes. Using elec. measurements and mass spectrometry, deuterons permeate through these crystals much slower than protons, resulting in a sepn. factor of ≈10 at room temp. The isotope effect is attributed to a difference of ≈60 milli-eV between zero-point energies of incident protons and deuterons, which translates into the equiv. difference in the activation barriers posed by two-dimensional crystals. In addn. to providing insight into the proton transport mechanism, the demonstrated approach offers a competitive and scalable way for hydrogen isotope enrichment.

Thousands of tons of isotopic mixts. are processed annually for heavy-water prodn. and tritium decontamination. The existing technologies remain extremely energy intensive and require large capital investments. New approaches are needed to reduce the industry's footprint. Recently, micrometre-size crystals of graphene are shown to act as efficient sieves for hydrogen isotopes pumped through graphene electrochem. Here we report a fully-scalable approach, using graphene obtained by chem. vapor deposition, which allows a proton-deuteron sepn. factor of around 8, despite cracks and imperfections. The energy consumption is projected to be orders of magnitude smaller with respect to existing technologies. A membrane based on 30 m2 of graphene, a readily accessible amt., could provide a heavy-water output comparable to that of modern plants. Even higher efficiency is expected for tritium sepn. With no fundamental obstacles for scaling up, the technol.'s simplicity, efficiency and green credentials call for consideration by the nuclear and related industries.

Proton transfer across single-layer graphene proceeds with large computed energy barriers and is therefore thought to be unfavorable at room temp. unless nanoscale holes or dopants are introduced, or a potential bias is applied. Here we subject single-layer graphene supported on fused silica to cycles of high and low pH, and show that protons transfer reversibly from the aq. phase through the graphene to the other side where they undergo acid-base chem. with the silica hydroxyl groups. After ruling out diffusion through macroscopic pinholes, the protons are found to transfer through rare, naturally occurring at. defects. Computer simulations reveal low energy barriers of 0.61-0.75 eV for aq. proton transfer across hydroxyl-terminated at. defects that participate in a Grotthuss-type relay, while pyrylium-like ether terminations shut down proton exchange. Unfavorable energy barriers to helium and hydrogen transfer indicate the process is selective for aq. protons.

Nafion 211 is the membrane of ref. for many fuel cell users, but the literature on its properties is sparse. Unlike previous embodiments of Nafion membranes, which are obtained by melt extrusion, Nafion 211 is prepd. by dispersion casting. This paper reports a range of properties obtained by ex situ and in situ characterization methods. Water uptake and proton cond. are studied as a function of temp. and relative humidity. The extent of dimensional changes of as-received membranes upon hydration is found to be independent of thermal treatment. At 25 °C and 97% RH the max. hydration no. is ∼12. Absorption from liq. water and vapor are obsd. to be similar. Proton cond. for Nafion 211 is reported up 80 °C and as a function of relative humidity. At 80 °C, the cond. increases from 0.0012 to 0.13 S/cm as RH is increased from 10 to 95%. The hydraulic permeability of Nafion 211 is 2.4 × 10-16 m2 Pa-1 s-1 at 70 °C and the permeance is 8.8 × 10-12 m Pa-1 s-1. Oxygen soly. and the diffusion coeff., studied using a solid state electrochem. cell, are 1.6 × 10-5 mol cm-3 and 1.04 × 10-6 cm2 s-1 at 30 °C, 100% RH, and 30 psi oxygen. Oxygen permeability is 1.71 × 10-11 mol cm-1 s-1 under similar conditions. In situ measurement of hydrogen crossover current is 1.2 mA/cm2 at 80 °C and 100% RH.

Methanol crossover due to the low selectivity of proton exchange membranes is a long-standing issue in direct methanol fuel cell technol. Here this issue is addressed by designing a composite membrane fabricated by sandwiching a monolayer graphene between two thin Nafion membranes to take advantage of monolayer graphene's selective permeability to only protons. The methanol permeability of the present membrane is demonstrated to have a 68.6% decrease in comparison to that of the pristine Nafion membrane. The test in a passive direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) shows that the designed membrane retains high proton cond. while substantially suppressing methanol crossover. As a result, the present membrane enables the passive DMFC to exhibit a decent performance even at a methanol concn. as high as 10.0 M.

The authors report the use of atomically thin layers of graphene as a protective coating that inhibits corrosion of underlying metals. Here, the authors employ electrochem. methods to study the corrosion inhibition of Cu and Ni by either growing graphene on these metals, or by mech. transferring multilayer graphene onto them. Cyclic voltammetry measurements reveal that the graphene coating effectively suppresses metal oxidn. and O redn. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy measurements suggest that while graphene itself is not damaged, the metal under it is corroded at cracks in the graphene film. Finally, the authors use Tafel anal. to quantify the corrosion rates of samples with and without graphene coatings. Cu films coated with graphene grown via CVD are corroded 7 times slower in an aerated Na2SO4 soln. as compared to the corrosion rate of bare Cu. Tafel anal. reveals that Ni with a multilayer graphene film grown on it corrodes 20 times slower while Ni surfaces coated with four layers of mech. transferred graphene corrode 4 times slower than bare Ni. These findings establish graphene as the thinnest known corrosion-protecting coating.

Recent dramatic progress in studying various 2-dimensional at. crystals and their heterostructures calls for better and more detailed understanding of their crystallog., reconstruction, stacking order, etc. For this, direct imaging and identification of each and every atom is essential. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) are ideal and perhaps the only tools for such studies. However, the electron beam can in some cases induce dramatic structure changes, and radiation damage becomes an obstacle in obtaining the desired information in imaging and chem. anal. in the (S)TEM. This is the case of 2-dimensional materials such as molybdenum disulfide MoS2, but also of many biol. specimens, mols., and proteins. Thus, minimizing damage to the specimen is essential for optimum microscopic anal. Here, the authors demonstrate, on the example of MoS2, that encapsulation of such crystals between two layers of graphene allows for a dramatic improvement in stability of the studied 2-dimensional crystal and permits careful control over the defect nature and formation in it. They present STEM data collected from single-layer MoS2 samples prepd. for observation in the microscope through three distinct procedures. The fabricated single-layer MoS2 samples were either left bare (pristine), placed atop a single-layer of graphene, or finally encapsulated between single graphene layers. Their behavior under the electron beam is carefully compared, and the authors show that the MoS2 sample sandwiched between the graphene layers has the highest durability and lowest defect formation rate compared to the other two samples, for very similar exptl. conditions.

An insulating 2-dimensional material, hexagonal BN (h-BN), is reported, which can be used as an effective wrapping layer for SERS substrates. This material exhibits outstanding characteristics such as its crystallinity, impermeability, and thermal conductance. Improved SERS sensitivity is confirmed for Au substrates wrapped with h-BN, the mechanism of which is studied via h-BN thickness-dependent expts. combined with theor. simulations. The studies reveal that a stronger electromagnetic field can be generated at the narrowed gap of the h-BN surface, which results in higher Raman sensitivity. The h-BN-wrapped Au substrate shows extraordinary stability against photothermal and oxidative damages. Its capability to detect specific chems. that are difficult to analyze using conventional SERS substrates is described. Probably this concept of using an h-BN insulating layer to protect metallic or plasmonic materials will be widely used not only in the field of SERS but also in the broader study of plasmonic and optoelectronic devices.

Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have recently received increasing attention because of their potential applications in semiconducting and optoelectronic devices exhibiting large optical absorptions in the visible range. However, some studies have reported that the grain boundaries of TMDs can be easily degraded by the presence of oxygen in water and by UV irradn., ozone, and heating under ambient conditions. We herein demonstrate the photodegrdn. of WSe2 and MoSe2 by laser exposure (532 nm) and the subsequent prevention of this photodegrdn. by encapsulation with hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) layers. The photodegrdn. was monitored by variation in peak intensities in the Raman and photoluminescence spectra. The rapid photodegrdn. of WSe2 under air occurred at a laser power of ≥0.5 mW and was not obsd. to any extent at ≤0.1 mW. However, in the presence of a water droplet, the photodegrdn. of WSe2 was accelerated and took place even at 0.1 mW. We examd. the encapsulation of WSe2 with h-BN and found that this prevented photodegrdn. However, a single layer of h-BN was not sufficient to fully prevent this photodegrdn., and so a triple layer of h-BN was employed. We also demonstrated that the photodegrdn. of MoSe2 was prevented by encapsulation with h-BN layers. On the basis of XPS and scanning photoemission microscopy data, we detd. that this degrdn. was caused by the photoinduced oxidn. of TMDs. These results can be used to develop a general strategy for improving the stability of 2D materials in practical applications.

A review. Besides cost redn., durability is the most important issue to be solved before commercialization of PEM Fuel Cells can be successful. For a fuel cell operating under const. load conditions, at a relative humidity close to 100% and at a temp. of max. 75 °C, using optimal stack and flow design, the voltage degrdn. can be as low as 1-2 μV·h. However, the degrdn. rates can increase by orders of magnitude when conditions include some of the following, i.e. load cycling, start-stop cycles, low humidification or humidification cycling, temps. of 90 °C or higher and fuel starvation. This review paper aims at assessing the degrdn. mechanisms of membranes, electrodes, bipolar plates and seals. By collecting long-term expts. as well, the relative importance of these degrdn. mechanisms and the operating conditions become apparent.

Mechanism for Degradation of Nafion in PEM Fuel Cells from Quantum Mechanics Calculations
Yu, Ted H.; Sha, Yao; Liu, Wei-Guang; Merinov, Boris V.; Shirvanian, Pezhman; Goddard, William A.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(

; ISSN:

.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Results are reported of quantum mechanics (QM) mechanistic studies of Nafion membrane degrdn. in a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell. Expts. suggest that Nafion degrdn. is caused by generation of trace radical species (such as OH·, H·) only when in the presence of H2, O2, and Pt. DFT is used to construct the potential energy surfaces for various plausible reactions involving intermediates that might be formed when Nafion is exposed to H2 (or H+) and O2 in the presence of the Pt catalyst. A barrier of 0.53 eV was found for OH radical formation from HOOH chemisorbed on Pt(111) and of 0.76 eV from chemisorbed OOHad, suggesting that OH might be present during the oxygen redn. reaction, particularly when the fuel cell is turned on and off. Based on the QM, 2 chem. mechanisms for OH radical attack on the Nafion polymer are proposed: (1) OH attack on the S-C bond to form H2SO4 plus a carbon radical (barrier: 0.96 eV) followed by decompn. of the carbon radical to form an epoxide (barrier: 1.40 eV). (2) OH attack on H2 crossover gas to form hydrogen radical (barrier: 0.04 eV), which subsequently attacks a C-F bond to form HF plus carbon radicals (barrier as low as 1.00 eV). This carbon radical can then decomp. to form a ketone plus a carbon radical with a barrier of 0.86 eV. The products (HF, OCF2, SCF2) of these proposed mechanisms have all been obsd. by F NMR in the fuel cell exit gases along with the decrease in pH expected from proposed mechanism.

Growth of high-crystalline, single-layer hexagonal boron nitride on recyclable platinum foil
Kim, Gwangwoo; Jang, A.-Rang; Jeong, Hu Young; Lee, Zonghoon; Kang, Dae Joon; Shin, Hyeon Suk
Nano Letters
(

; ISSN:
1530-6984
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) is gaining significant attention as a two-dimensional dielec. material, along with graphene and other such materials. Herein, we demonstrate the growth of highly cryst., single-layer h-BN on Pt foil through a low-pressure chem. vapor deposition method that allowed h-BN to be grown over a wide area (8 × 25 mm2). An electrochem. bubbling-based method was used to transfer the grown h-BN layer from the Pt foil onto an arbitrary substrate. This allowed the Pt foil, which was not consumed during the process, to be recycled repeatedly. The UV-visible absorption spectrum of the single-layer h-BN suggested an optical band gap of 6.06 eV, while a high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy image of the same showed the presence of distinct hexagonal arrays of B and N atoms, which were indicative of the highly cryst. nature and single-atom thickness of the h-BN layer. This method of growing single-layer h-BN over large areas was also compatible with use of a sapphire substrate.
